div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

cell.p: Subscribed Capital

div.p: The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

p.hi: MR. GLADSTONE'S PROTEGES.

It would be almost incredible, if the infor mation did not come from himself, that ih Baglish Home Secretary stould be ignorant whether thirty French Anarchists bave or have aot recently obtaicei entrance in to Great Britain by the simple expedient of declaring themselves polit cal refagees. Sir Willian Svans Gordon baz tot at his disposal the means of informstion baturally possessed by

Minister, but he appears to ba pretty sure of his facts, and the Home Secretary, the map who of all others ongbt to be the most fully informed in the country on such a matter, has to content himself with the easy argument that the facts are not accorately stated," and is efficially in complete ignorance of the arrival, the character, or the purpose of bese men. In face of the recrudescecce of he abominable doctrines of anarchy, and of be frightful example we have so recently bad of what it means in practice, it was surely the special duty of the Minister oharged with the administration of the Aliens Act to see that the asylum provided by England is not sbased. Mr. Gladstone, however, appears to

ske a different view of bis responsibilities, and is in a fair way to make bimself responsible for a great invasion of procure8888, pandare, prostitute psapers, and 858988ids. In some case> - we judge by his own statements--because them to receive a benevolent warning from the British authorities that they really ought not to ply their particular trades in Bogland and that he will have to be quite barsh with them i they do. He disapproves, wonderful to relate of the practice of pagper aliens borrowing a five-pound note in order to satisfy the im

migration officers that they are ia possession of visible means of sabai tance, but his heart fails him when it comes to the point of actually deporting a Polish woman convicted of solicitation in the streets of London; while Las for the invading . Anarchists, be is still
making inquiries." How these interestice people mast bless and mast laogh at the tender hearted, timorous Minister who rules the Homa Office jast now!

The allegations made by Sir William Evans Gordon are quite specific, and we only hope be will not desist trom questioning Mr. Gladstone on the sobject before be bas snovbeded in rousing him to some sense of his daty. We may be pretty sure that these allegations have at least a substantial basis, or else Mr. Gladstone would not content himself with so banal a criticism as that they are "Got accur. ately stated," but would contradict them at once. It he really does not know whether thirty notorious French Anarchista bave recently entered Great Britain or not at New haven he is worse served by his police than any Home Secretary who ever lived, sod we simply decline to believe that the French and English police are so atterly incompetent for their daties as to be without information on a movement of such dimensions on the part of the most dangerous acd desperate of the enemies of sociaty. Mr. Gladstone may see fit for purposes of his own to maintain an official ignorance, but we hope his interrogators will not rest until they have extracted from him & statement as to what information, if any, has been farbished him on the subject by the police. What his motives may be for evading, or trying to evade the issue we neither know nor care. He may fear the personal vengeance of his protégés if be distarbs their very anstable equanimity, or be may be in dread of the political consequences of resolate aotion. So far as the country is concerned, the effect is pretty much the same in either case, for London is made the damping-ground for the vilest sooandrels in Barope, who come there ander his æzis to foal da with their filth. The present Government is not usually classed among the Vertebrates, but we do at least want some sort of backbone in the Home Office ; and if Mr. Gladstone is unable to develop an organ of that kind, the sooner be gives place to some less mollasco as personAge the better for the country and for his own peace of mind. After all, even in the Radical party, there are men who are not afraid to "make their willa and do their daty," and to risk even the denonciations of the Porwarda ic order to keep England fairly clean.

Very po: sibly it is not want of courage, per sodal or political, which i 38 Mr. Gladstone's hands, but only a blind attachment to the ides of Eogland as the asylum for the oppressed. If it be so, tbe case is made no better, for assared. ly no Anarchist will for a moment credit him with any sentiment bat fear. Any sort of gratitude is unknown to these vermin, to whom vauity and the blood lust are the only springs of action. We have been told again and again tbat Eoglish immanity-Dot so very complete after all—from Anarchist attempts has been due to the toleration wh'ch has been shower those who profess these diabolical opinions. How little there is to build apon in such a theory is shown by the fact that they chose England as the place in which to batch 039 of their most atrocious plots, and that its ubject was an Eaglish Princess, whom they purposed to blow limb from limb apon her wedding day. Soch imnunity sa we posse:8 we

we to the fact that, with sil its faults, the Metropolitan Police manages to keep a absrp eye on these wretches, and that we have not hitherto been affiliated with Home Secretaries of the type of Mr. Herbert Gladstone. If be proceeds as he is doing wa-sball not enjoy our im nunity for long. As it is, foreigo Dations justly reproach us with permitting the enemies of the homan race to make the capital of our Empire not only their refage bat their base. Iacitement to morder and clorification of the murderers are to be found every day in sheets which are pablished in Lon !on, but of which, because they are invariably printed in Yasdeutsch, the general pablic knows nothing. Mr. Gladstone, however, is not the genera! pab'ic, and he has plenty of subordinates to whom this jargon is perfactly familiar. Yet, with the knowledge which he must have, or, at the least, could have at the est of tbe most saperficial ingairy, he presumes to exercise a dispensing power in regard to the one Act which is our security against the invasion of disease, prostitution, and anarchy, and does not even take the trouble to find out whether the thirty Frenchmen who have landed at . Newhaven ars or are not the advocates of the most abouninable crimes, and the scomplices of the most fiendish criminala,
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
The Plague.
No case of plagne has been reported during the past two daye. One recovery took place at Samalout yesterday. The Brindlel Mall.
The mail from Europe, viA Brindisi and Port Said, will arrive at Alexandria at 3.5 p.m. to day and will be ready for distribution at 4.30 p.m. Nassan Boy Wassef's Case.
It is reported that Hassan Bey Wassef, ex Mondir of Ghirgeh, will be released from prison at the end of this month, his health having broken down.
Al Azhar
The Sheikh of Bl Azhar University has drawn up a series of regulations to be observed by visitors, which are to be submitted to the approval of the Ministry of the Interior. Mixed Couřte.
It is said that the Council of Ministers bas requested the Judicial Adviser (who left yesterday for England) to select a Portuguese judge for the Mixed Tribunals on his way.
Urbanor.
The management of Urbanors have kindly offered to devote to morrow's seance to the Alexandria foundlings and the inmates of the orphanages. The general publio will therefore not be admitted
Virtue Rewarded.

The Government has granted a reward of ME. 75 to Abon Eisha Hamad, abeikh of the Bl Djazuwi Bedouins, who repaleei an attack made by an armed gang and arrested one of thom. His son was killed in the affray. Burned to Death.

On the evening of the 18th inst., native girl of Toukh, while poaring petrolem into a stove, set her clothes on fire and received auch severe barns that she suo0umbed to ber injories in a few hours. The fire spread and destroyed several houses before being pat ont. Outrage at Fashn.

An outrage is reported from Fashp, where shots were fired at the avsistant atation master Ismail Effendi Ali, and at a pointsman while on duty on the night of Jane 17. Ismail Effendi received a severe wound, the pointsman, Tabami Gidawi by name, getting off with slight injaries. Both have been sent to the Governa ment Hospital at Beni Sonef and an official enquiry bag boon opened into the osse. £1,000 Damages

The French Consular Court in Cairo bas condemned the Cairo Gas Company to pay Mt. A. Samuelson, of the Mixed Tribunals, the sum of fr. 25,000 as damages for injuries received by the plaintiff in 1904. Mr. Samuel sop, while walking out at night, fell into a trenoh, which the Gas Company had dog aoroas a road to repair some leakages in the gas-pipes, and wbich was marked by no lantern or sigo. An Unpleasant Experience.

The passengers by the fast train leaving Bab el Lonk Station, Cairo, at 7.80p.m. yesterday had the bopleasant experience of a complate breakdown at Saida Zonab station. Here they waited and waited till some impatient spirits left the train and trudget home. Others oontinued to wait till the arrival of a relief train, which brought them to Helonan at an unearthly hour. A contemporary states that the coal had been forgotten!
Sisownth's Splendour.

King Sisowath, of Cambodis, who, as an noupoed by Havas to-day, has arrived at Paris, was surrounded by his Ministers and retainers when the French officials went on board the ship to waloome him at Marseilles. He wore a smoking jacket, silk knee breeches, and a sword, the hilt of which was of gold set with diamonds. His hat was of a bowler shape, the side looped up with a golden cockade, the colours of his kingdom being set out in precious stones. Near the potentate, says the "Chronicle's" correspondent, were his three personal attendants. Das carried a golden cigarette oase with the King's initials in diamonds, a second bore & matchbox set with rabies, while the third Carried a golden spittoon for his Majesty's Brelasive use.

DENISHWAI OUTRAGE.
PROGRESS OF THE ENQUIRY.
CAPT. BULL'S BODY EXHUMED.
(From our SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).

Denish wai, Tuesday. Two of the guna tákon from the British officers have been discovered in the house of A native of Denishwai who had not yet been pnt under arrest, and is said to have assisted the anthorities with information as to the participants in the affray.

p.hi: Late on Sunday evening Mr. Machell and * British doctor arrived at the Mounted Infantry camp, and after an interview with the officer in command proceeded to the El Sohada police ontpost, where the Mondir, the Chef do Parquet, and the Secretary of the Parquet were awaiting them and passed the night there. This morning all of them - including the Adviser - came to the British camp, where they eat in the large tent ereoted near the Bagonrieb Canal, and opened an enquiry into the Sirsina incidents. As to the dead man found at Sirsina, the commander of the patrol and his men declared that they knew nothing of the matter. Two natives who asserted that the soldiers had killed him could not identify any man or bring any proof beyond their bare assertion.

div.p: Returning to the Denish wai outrage, a British offiser who tormed one of the party 09 the 18th 'And Capt. Boatook, R.A.M.C., were confronted with 52 natives of the village and identified two more, among them the man in whose hoase two gune Eere found. The number of the accused is now 77.
Ibrahim Bey Holbawi, representative of the Parquet, who came to Danishwai to-day, is leaving this evening, but returns to morrow,

Mr. Macbell, the Moudir of Menonfieb province, and the Chef do Parquet leave to night for Shibin el kom, where the trial will probably take place on Sunday. The police detachment sont dowa from Cairo bas returned.

p.hi: A enb inspector of the Ministry of the Interior bas jurt arrived and will accompany th a British troops to Alexandria. The Mounted lofantry start on Friday for Shibin-el Kom, where they will attend the examination, and then march down to Alexandria.

div.p: To discover whether there were any grounds for the belief that sparks from a gun oould ignite a "gir" at a distance even less that that which separated the British officers from the "girn" which oaught fire on the 13th inst., the authorities tried the experiment of detailing soldiers to fire at a pile of oorn at a distance of 60 metres. I need not say that the discharger had no effect whatever.
TL

p.hi: The Ministry of the Interior made the tollowing communication to the Press this morning: -

With reference to the general regime of the ooourrence at Denish wai on the 13th inst., it appears that Abdel Mogid Bay Sultan did not offer to send the carriages to take the officers to shoo, but that the Mamour of Menouf telephoned to Abdel Megid Bey Saltan's brother, the Omdeb of Elwad, informing bim that the officers wanted to go and requesting him to afford facilities. Accordingly, it is stated that Abdel Megid's brother sent the carriages without bis brother's knowledge.
We are requested to contradiot the report appoxring in other papers that the scaffold at the Police Stores, Boalao, was tested yesterday morning and afterwards sent to Denishwai.

It having been asserted that the death of the late Captain Bull might be due to gunstroke, the Commandant of Police gave orders for the exhumation of the deceased offiser's body for the parpose of making a post-mortem examination. The body was exhumed this morning and the antopsy is being held by Dr. Nolan.
The official papers of the inquiry regarding the Danish wai outrage will probably be submitted to the members of the Special Court to-day.
EGYPT & LEVANT STEAMSHIP CO.

We nderstand that the Egypt and Levant Steamship Co. has just acqaired a new steamer of 6,000 tons dead weight for £37,500, or about £6.3.0 per ton. This vessel, which is of the latest type, and will be launcbed on the 23rd instant, will be ready for Bes by the end of Jaly. It is specially adapted to the opion osrrying trade, which is so important an item in Alexandris, as also the Smyrna dried fruit business and Levant exporte. This is an excellent bargain.
THE SUCRERIES

The Hon. A. J. Davey, M. Ternynck, and M. Arbib bave resigned their positions as directors of the Soiété des Sacreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte. They are replaced by M. Raphael Suarès, Harari Pachs, and Birch Pachs, wbo bave been formally appointed directors. M. Naus is appointed general manager, and Harari Pacha beoc mes managing director. Two more directors will be appointed in the pear future.

CAIRO RAILWAY STATION
AN INNOVATION.
COMPLETE SYSTEM OF ELECTRIC
.. SIGNALLING.

Friday last will for ever be a red-letter day in the history of railway and eleotrioal enterprise in Africa, for on that day the work of fitting the Cairo station of the State Railways with a complete system of electrio signalling was fibisbed. Io our issue of the 9th Janoary last we gave our readers a short account of the opening of the first instalment of the new Bystem and we then explained in the briefesta terms the general principle upon which it is founded, pointing out the reasons that render it an almost indispensable aid to the watej working of the station. From the interest shown in that article we believe the complimentary details we are now able to give will be acceptable.

As stated in our previous article, the system a lopted at Cairo is that knows as the Westing house electrio-pneumatio signalling system, and it is one that is yearly obtaining higher and faller recognition as in every way one of the most efficient methods of providing for the increasing exigencies of the railway services of the world, the steadily growing expe. rience of its operation that is being gained on the many lines on which it has been introdooed going to attest in the fullest manner all the olaims originally made for it by its in. ventor. An outline of its application at Cairo will show, when taken with what we have said in tha article to which we have referred, the many advantages of the system. So numerous are the lines of rail within the limits of that station, ovunting only those connectod with the main line to Alexandria and the connec. tion with the Matarieh line and the goods yard and other purely local lines, and 80 complex is the traffis that daily passed over thane lines, that it requires, we understand, over sixty diffarent signals to direct the fi drivers of trains and engines in entering or li leaving or moving about the station,

Under the old system of signals the alteration of each sigoal and the locompanying points demanded the services of a number of mon situated in different parts of the atation and workiog and operating the signals i and points as far as could be obtained in harmony the one with the other. Unfortanately, no matter how efficient or how carefall these men might be, mistakes and errors were often of a nature which only the occurrence of an accident or visible error of some kind, gach As the passing of a train to & wrong line, could deteot. This has been, as our readers are aware, the cause of almost all the serious accidents that have cocurred in Eorope or America, and it was the knowledge of this fact that lead to the invention of the systems of interlocking, as it is called, that have now been made compulsory by law on all the railways of England and we believe in some if not all the countries of Europe.

By all these systems, a large number of It points and signals baing brought under the charge of one man, the old risk of two or more mea giving conflicting signals or making movements of the points or signals inconsistant with the safety of a train being moved by another man was practically rendered im possible. This was at first accomplished by the use of mechanical contrivances, and for all but the largest and most complicated stations these are as yet Boffizient. But in stations, such as Cairo, where there is not only a heavy traffic to be guided, but where that traffio is conducted under disadvantages of space, eto, the most efficient purely me chanioal systems leave something to be desired.

This something and more than it is sapplied by the Westinghouse system, by the aid of which three men are able to fally and perfect ly control the whole of the traffic within the limits we have mentioned, that is to say, to operate with safety and certainty not only the sixty sigaals bat all the points and safety apparatus connected with these. This is rendered possible by the combination of pneumatic and electric power, the former supplying the force required to move the signals, eto., and the latter the controlling power that brings that force into play exactly at the cost of a minimam of physical exertion on the part of the operator.

As we have said before, we consider that the Railway Administration is to be complimented in the amplest manner for the enterprise it has shown in the adoption of this system, and the officials may congratulate themselves apon the good fortune which has enabled them to bring the work to a successfal head thrøagh the able and energetic co operation of Mr. Panter, the chief of the Signal Department; Mr. Hatt, his indefatigable en. gineer, and Mr. Kussell, the special delegate of the Westinghouse Co., who has from the first been in charge of the whole of the details of the work and has been rasponsible for its efficiency.
UM RUS GOLD MINES.

Mr. Harvey, presiding at the meeting of the Um Ras Gold Mines of Egypt (Limited), said that gold mining was very speculative, and they hsd no reason whatever to doubt that they won'd come out all right in the end. Had it not been for the failure of part of the machinery, they would have had no need to ask them to reconstruct the company. In order to vigorously develop the property they would require more fands, and therefore it was proposed to form & Dew company, with a capital
of £180,000. e! The proposal was agreed to.
NOTES FROM CYPRUS.
NICOSIA - LARNACA RAILWAY.
BONDED STORES FOR FAMAGUSTA.
(From our CORRESPONDENT).

Larnaca, Juna 7. There is a rumour, which is credibly received, that the projected railway line from Nicosia to Larnaca is agaio under the consideration of the Colonial Office. That such a line would be a grest convenience to the nomerong travellers between the two placey does not admit of a doubt. Whether the amount of goods traffic is at present sufficiently important, or copld by the establishment of a line of railway be inpressed Boas to become gofficiently so, to jnstify the construction of such & line, is a debateable point.

Another project, of which there is some talk, is that of forming a Bonded Warehouse at Pamagusta. This was a favourite scheme of the late High Commissioner, Sir W. Haynes Smith, but up to the present time no definite steps, beyond the accomolation, presumably, of data and general information bearing on the sobject, have been taken. It is generally believed that the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allot ment Company view favoorably the creation of sach bonded stores at that port, and I trust that the idea may gradually assume boncrete shape. Famagusta is admirably suited, both as regards her situation and the plan on which she is built, for such a purpose, and a very general opinion prevails that she would attract

large volame of trade from the coasts of Asia Minor 'and Syria, where at present bonded wareboosemen ara heavily taxed in the way of "baokbeesh." In this connection it may be noted that in January lost an Order in Council was issued by the High Commissioner, making regulations for the establisbment and management of warehouse, other than Customs Bonded Warehouses, for the warehousing and securing of goods without payment of Customs import duty upon the first ontry of the same into the Island. The only goods prohibited from being warehoused onder these regulations were tobacco, manofactured or unmanufactured, spirits, bashish, firearmg,gånpowder, cartridges and explosive substances, as defined by Ordi. nanog IV. of 1882, petroleum and other inflammable substances, as defined by Law II. of 1892, matches, bricks and tiler, cement, earthenware not in packages, goods of a perishable natare. Stroot Lighting.

The Municipality of Nicosia bag lately brought itself before the public eye and has given evidence of a somewhat unusual pablio Bpirit. It has erected several fine, brilliant lamps in the principal streets of the town. and the prblic are daly grateful for its action. Street lighting as sach has been hitherto all bat non-existent, the few crazy oil lamps that were nightly lit having scarcely repaid the trouble of lighting them. S. P. C. A.

The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals held its annual meeting on the 24th May last, and was able to show another year's record of good work done. Its chief activity lies in the maintenance of a hospital | stable in Nicosia where sick and lame apimals are received and treated. The number of cases 80 treated during the year ended 31st March last was 73, compared with 40 during the previous year, and it is a sign of its popularity, and that it has won the confidence of the people, that in the majority of cases the villagers have brought in their soffering animals of their own accord. The society from the outset took the view that its action should be rather to incalcate humane habits among the villager than to exercise panitive measures. By so doing the society is gradually winning over pablic opi. nion to assist it in realizing its objects. It numbers many of the leading members of the three principal sections of the community among its membere, and they are also represented on the committee. The Locust Plague,

A proclamation by the High Commissioner in Council bas jost been gezetted whereby the collection of the locust tax is suspended. This tax, which was created for the purpose of providing a fand wherewith to combat the locust plagae, ander provisions of a law passed in 18-1, has been levied on most of the property-owning and professional classes of the Laland, bat on nope does it fall Bo Beverely as apon the Government official. These officiale, indeed, are among the very few who derived no benefit direct or indirect from the fand, and it is not unnaturally regarded by them 89 a somewhat onressonable tax to levy apon them. The locusts of recent years have very
greatly diminished, and the sum required to - be raised annually for the locust campaign is

consequently much less than formerly. Whereas in former years it was necessary to adopt the "screen and pie" system, the collection is Dow made by catching the locusts in bage prepared in the sbape of fly-nets of large siza. In 1881 it is estimated that no less than 1,305 tons of eggs were destroyed, at a cost of £11.918 ; in 1905, 367 millions of live locoste were caught at an expenditure of £3,C31. The Mall Contract.

His Excelleacy visited Pamsgasta yesterday in order to inspect the Lefkosia, one of the twin vessels (be other being the Kyprios) belonging to the Limaseol Steamship Company which have been recommended to receive the cntract for carrying the mails between Cyprus and Egypt. The contract, however, has not yet been cfficially announced. Summer Heat,
Summer heat has now get in after a spell of exceptionally dull, cool weather, and the departure of the Government to Troodos will probably take place before the end of the preI sent month.
RAINS OF NILE BASIN.
SURVEY DEPARTMENT REPORT.
lopment of Welayed. From
infall.totale

We have received from the Barvoy Department a valuable and interosting report drawn op by Capt. Lyons on the rains in the Nile Basin in 1905. The following summary of the results obtained in quoted from the report :

In 1905 the collection of data concerning | the rainfall within the Nile Basin was ex tended more widely, and a number of now rain ganga stations were established. Besides this, a number of posta throughout the Sodan, at which no measuroments of the raintall are made, furnished fortnightly returns showing the days on which light, moderate, or heavy rain fell. Though these retorn, do not lead as yet to any definite ponolasions, it is hoped that they will gradually farnish material by means of which the distribution of rainfall on the Badan plains may be studied.

The Egyptian and Sudan stations at which the rainfall is measured only number 31, the remainder being situated in the neighbouring territories of Erythrea, Uganda, British Bast Atrion, German Eust Africa, and British Central Africa, from all of which information bas been most generously supplied.

Captain Tanpredi of Aldi Ugri hay sent much meteorological information from Erythren and the Captain of the Port has done the sang from Mansowah. The Director of the Scientific Department of Uganda and the Director of the Agrionltural Department of British East Africa have contributed rainfall and other data both in the form of monthly retards and of telegrams in the early summer when the development of tbe rains in the southern Sadan was much delayed. From Dar es Salam in German East Africa the weekly rainfall.totals published in the Deutsch Ostafrikanische Zait. ung" have been sent and have been of much interest, though the inland stations are more important for the porpose of judging the northward movement of the rains, but natuTally in view of the great distances to be travered, it is impossible as yet to get information from such stations in time to atilize it.

This was the first year that an attempt bas been made to collectioformation from a wide ares and to dedooe from it the probable development of the East African monsoon in its northern extension, and much study is still necessary before it can b: said precisely what information' is more useful and what weight should be given to such evidence as excess or deficiency of rain in different areas. The same is trae of other meteorological factors which have been less observed, and the effect of whish is consequently lees knowo. Dr. G. | Walker, P.R. S., tha Meteorological Reporter

to the Government of India, telegraphed weekly the deviations of the mean barometrio reading from the normal for Mauritius, Seychelles, Zanzibar and Adon, which were of the greatest service for oomparison with the pressure deviations of Egypt and the Sadan. That the experience gained in 1905 should lead to a reliable basis for forecasting the Abyssinian rainfall, would be too sanguine & view to adopt, but a carefal stady of the meteorological conditions which have prevailed for the past 15 years over Africa to the north of lat. | 108., supplemented by the yearly increas.
ing data, both meteorological and hydrograIphical, may fairly be expected to throw light on this most interesting and important problem.

It may be said that on tha whole the rainfall was everywhere deficient; the volume of the Nile flood was only 0.65 of an average flood, thus adding another year to the long series of | low floods which has now continued for 10 years, only two of th399 having slightly exceeded the average, while the other eight have been mach below it.
CATTLE PLAGUE.

The weekly cattle resort issued by the Public Health Department shows that during the week ending last Saturday there were six fresh cases notified, namely, two at Biahmo, one at Bzbet Farag Guirgais, one at Bzbet Ibrahim Pasha, one at Kasba el Gedida (all of the Fayoum Mondi ieh), and one at El Keratying, in the Moudirieb of Ghizeh.
GREEK PATRIARCH OF ANTIOCH.

Advices from Damascus announce that his Beatitude Mgr. Gregorios Haddad, Greek Orthodox Archbishop of Tripoli ia Syria, has been appointed Patriarch of Antioch. Mgr. Haddad, who is a Syriso, has been arobbishop of Tripoli for fifteen years, and is now 47. He speaks Greek, Turkish, and Arabic.
SAN STEFANO CASINO.

The management of the Casino inform og that the cecond vocal and instrumental concert will take place to morrow, when the new artistes, Sig. Grandi (tenor) and Signs. DespoBito (contralto), will take part. The following is the programme, which is certain to attract a large crowd to the Casico. The rooal part

PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.

As we reported in our issue of yesterday, Lord and Lady Cromer lett Cairo by special saloon attached to the 11 am, train to Port Said, where they immediately embarked on. the P. &0. 8.8. Persia. A large number of people wore at the station to bid Lord and Lady Cromer "au revoir," among whom we notioed their Bxcellencies Mustapha Pachs Pebmy, Hassein, Pacha Pakhry, Boutros Pachs Ghali, Abmed Mazloom Pache, Mohamed Aby ni Paoba, Mr. and Mrs. M. de C. Findlay, Mr. Romboldt, Mr. and Mrs. Alban, Bir Vinoont Corbett, General Bollock, Bir Reginald Wingate Pacha, Colonel Cathbert, Crookshapk Pacha and Mrs. Crooksbank, Mansfield Pachs, Very Rev. Dean Batober, Major Johnston, Captain Hall, Hon. P. Iddings, U.8. Diplomatic Agent and Consal General, and many others.
Bir Malcolm Mollwraith, who is also leaving by the Persia, was passenger by the same train.
The Sirdar is expected to arrive at Alex. andria this evening. Sir Reginald Wingate will inspect the Egyptian garrison of the city to-morrow, and leaves for England on Saturday.
De Martino Paoba, who received a command from the Khedive to meet his Highness at Vienna, has left for Austria.
M. Gandadis, the retiring Hellenio Diplomatio Agent and Consul-General in Cairo, is leaving this afternoon for Athene.

Among the passengers leaving by the Norddeutscher Lloyd steamer Nobleswig this afternoon are Ahmed Djellaleddin Pacha, Chakoor Pacba, Mastapha Pachs Kamel, Adly Pasha Yeghen and Mme. Yeghen, Mr. Consal Hellwig, Ibrahim Bay Orphi, Saleh Sabit Pachs, M. Michel Salvago, Mr. Freeman, eto.

M. G andmoulin, bead of the Khedivial Law School, Cairo, has resigned, and the position has been offered to Hussein Bey Rashdi, Counsellor in the Native Court of Appesl, who is said to have agreed to accept the post if he were guaranteed a permanent tenure of the same.

A farewell dinner was given on the 24th May by the members of the Baglish Club, Nikosia, to Captain A. H. Young, C.M G., on the occasion of his departure from Cyprus to take ap the duties of his new appointment as Chief Secretary at the Straits Settlements. Captain Young hu a record of 98 years' service in the Cyprus Government, and his departare is a great event in the history of the Island ander British occa pation.
BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
Le marché ferme à l'ouverture à continué en assez bɔnne tendance pour finir plas taible sur de grosses réalisations.
Agricole est stationnaire à 9 11/16, la National Bank à 25 9/16. 1. Les Tramways d'Alexandrie taiblissent de i franc à 193 1/2.
Les Obligations Crédit Foncier Egyptien haussent de fes. 0.50 à 325 l'ancienne et à 371 la nouvelle.
Nous lisons dans la Revue Economique da Paris :

" Nous apprenons que le Conseil d'administration de Crédit Foncier Egyptien va procéder incessamment à un appel de 125 frs. sur ses action. Cette mesure remble être inspirée par le développement toujours croissant des affaires de cette société et par le désir d'établir une meilleare proportion entre | le capital effectivement versé et le nombre des obligations foncières en circulation. .

"Les statuts attribuant un intérêt fixe do 6% an capital versé, la capitalisation de l'action, qui est au cours actuel de 4 % deviendrait donc supérieure à la suite de la susdite mesore. En effet l'intérêt à 6 pour cent sur 250 fre. versés est de 15 fr. ; en admettant an dividende complémentaire égal à celui de l'exercice écoulé, soit 7,50 le dividende total à distribuer aux actions serait de 22.80, ce qui représente 4 3/2 % sur la coors actuel de 750 fr." 1 La Banque d'Atbènes réactionne de 1 1/2 à 155 1/4.
La Delta Land se maintient à 3 15/16.
Les Trast et les Estates n'éproavent aucun changement.
La Salt & Soda est délaissée.
Le Comptoir fibancier fléchit de 1/32 à 6 1/8. Les actions de cette société ont été admises la cota de la Bourse du Caire. | Le Crédit Franco-Egyptien perd 1/16 à 5 1/8.
La Banque d'Orient c!tore à 133 1/2 après avoir atteint, toujours sar des découverts, 136 en cours de séance.

WORSE THAN ODESSA.
QUESTION IN PARLIAMENT.
ANGLO-RUSSIAN UNDERSTANDING
IMPOSSIBLE
ST. PETERSBURG, Jane 19. Three Dams delegates who have gone to Bielostok state that the massacre is worse than that of Odessa.

p.hi: (Router)

div.p: LONDON, June 19. The great Jewish financial houses are moy. ing most actively to prevent a recurrence of the massaoros. Lord Rothschild has interview od Sir B. Grey.

p.hi: (Ruter)

div.p: LONDON, June 19. House of COMMONS.-Sir E. Grey stated, in reply to a question, that he could not make representations to Rassis, and that it was pre mature to ask the Admiralty to alter the arrangements for the visit of the Fleet to Kronstadt.
After prolonged disoassion the closure resolution was adopted by 269 votes to 121.
Mr. Arquith bas intimated that the Govern mont desired to adjourn on the 4th Angust.

p.hi: (Reuter)

div.p: LONDON, June 19. Papers of all shades arge the impossibility of an Anglo-Russian understanding in view of the massacres at Bielostok. They sympathise with the Labourites' demand to cancel the Kronstadt demonstration.
The Daily Telegraph" expresses the hope that no further loan will be granted to Russia.

p.hi: (Router)

div.p: DURBAN, Jane 19. Zala rebels attacked a store near Mapumok during the night, and killed the owner and wounded two troopers. They captared a convoy of 7 waggons in the same district. One troope was wounded and another is missing. (Reuter
REVOLT IN FRENCH CONGO.
WHITE AGENT MURDERED.
BOMA, Jane 19. The natives in the Kwango district have revolted. Many factories have been looted, and a white agent has been mordered and anothe wounded.
(Router)
PREMIER AND CHINESE LABOUR.
RECEIVES DEPUTATION.

LONDON, Jane 19. Radioal dissatisfaction with the Chinese po licy of the Government culminated yesterday, when a deputation to Sir H. Campbell Baunerman, representing 166 Commoners, demanded the stoppage of the importation of Chinese to the Rand and the deportation of those already there.

Sir H. Campbell-Banderman, replying in 'general terms, said that it it were necessary, the Government would issae a clearer repatriation proclamation, but it could not in any case, agree to the experiment being andaly prolonged.

At the last sitting of the Prenob Academy o R. Noiences, says the "Temps," M. Darboux resc

a letter from a correspondent who called atten tion to the defective situation of Greenwich Observatory on acoount of the many factorie in the vicinity, and asked whether the Green wich meridian will be preserved should the Observatory be transferred to another place The correspondent ooncluded by suggesting the general adoptįon of the meridian of Bethlebem. This is the suggestion mvde at one
time by Father Tondini de Quarenghi, who I declared that because Beth ebem is in Massul mau territory both Christianity and Islam would be ready to accept such a meridian.

the international exbibition which will be open ed at Dublin in May 1907-in connection with which Sir Rowland Blenderhansett has left for Paris--we are informed that an Anglo-Preneb exhibition, commercial and industrial, will be held in London in 1908. div.p: IUS PHYSICAL DRILL
BY LIEUTENANT-COLONEL F A. DAVEY

Many years ago Lord Wolseley, in a publi speech, dwelt on the importance of not harass ing the soldier. Upon that text "Times correspondent sent a letter from India calling attention to the Army Medical Blae book fo 1876, in which there is an Appendix (No 6 giving a tall account of a particular system o Army training whiob really serves to harass the soldier to a degree. He is not only harassed but injured in health, by this system of train ing. Much attention jnst now is being giver to the question of Army effoiency,and it seems therefore, opportune to call attention once again to this matter.

The indictment in the Blue book is a serions one Indead, its very seriousness, probably, bas much to do with the fact that no military notice has been taken of it.Theallegation is that there is in the training of reoruita a practice which, while intended to benefit them on their own account, and for the sevice of the State, is onloplated to defast those ends, instead of favouring them. The Blue-book quoted claima to be an explanation of the enormous waste of the Army, and that the claim hög some foon. dation in justified by the fact that it finden place, and is propounded in an official book. Bither it should not be there at all, or, being there, it should be treated seriously. Never theless, some thirty years bave elapred, and nothing has been done to remedy an officially. admitted evil.

The evil is this, that the drill sergeant inter feres with the natural breathing of the mon onder bis command by directing them to expand the obest when there is no physiological demand for such expansion. This domand arisos naturally as the result of active exercise, bat in the standing attitude of attention, when no active physical exercise is taking place, this expansion of th: chest is ordered inst the same.

Colonel Pollock, who has under training one hundred men at Honnslow-mon who are not Army reoruits, but who are undergoing a military training-has deoided to omit the injurious item of the training condemned in the Blue book, and to allow his men perfoot freedom as to their breathing. The argo. mont bas appealed to him. He has roognised that, as a military horse can be trained to do all that is required of it-its breathing being a matter of no concern to the authorities-PO OANA man be made to do all that is ever likely to be required of him in hard work and military exercicer, while leaving his breathing to take oare of itself. The borse is improved : that is, trained. The man, by having bis attention direoted to his breathing (which should be automatically regulated) is injured. The invaliding retorns prove this.

The derartion of young reorgits, who are harassed"-indeed, the word is far too mild - by the disease-prodaoing and foolish process which they undergo emphasises the fact. And it is well to say he:e that the more loyally and faithfully a man obeys the order for

"developing his chest"-as the process is called-be more severely does be soffer. In a word, the drill sergeant's chest-swelling system is a superstition, and, like most superstitions, only does harm. Anyone who likes to experience the distress indooed by this obest-swelling, as inflicted on soldiers (that is, on those of them wbo obey), oan prove the matter for himself. Military drill, of which we have heard so much lately, and which is so much demanded and belauded, would be the exoellent thing it is held to be, if only it were parged of this chest-swelling.

What, then, is wrong about chest-swelling? The fall answer je in Appendix No. 6 of the Army Medical Blue-book for 1876. Ooly a cortailed one can be given here. Briefly it is this : that the expansion of the chest, as carried out in the Army, produces a disturbance of the balance which exists in bealth between the pulmonary and the systemic circulations. It soldier who is faithfully standing with his chest expanded in the attitude of "attention," the act of inspiration does not give place to a properly. performed expiration because the chest has to be kept "expanded.". Now expiration is as necessary and as physiologioal an aot as inspiration. The former should be as deep as the latter, and under natural condi

tion, being antomatically regulated, is so. this artificial system the aid to the polmonai circulation which expiration gives is to a grei extent withheld, and consequently the rig! cavities of the heart become ove filled from the system veine, while the left cavities al receiving less arterialired blood for distributia to the system. Breathlessness and distres according to the degree of this disturbance
balance, are an inevitablo resnlt. Hol Distress signifies strain on heart and lon

The latest edition of the "Syllabne of Physics Exercises for use in Pablio Elementary Schools admits this (page 25), yet advises this atrair ing attitode of attention. Strain on heart an Inge meant changes in those organe, forb anch atrain there is established a disturbano of the balance between the pulmonary and to systemic circulation- balance which exista in proper health. And o cardino hypertrophy commencing in the right side, igret np. wit! irritability of the heart, and breathlessness Ol Alight exertion. It may be well bere to quoti from a recent comment made by Professo Arthur Keith, Lecturer on Anatomy in the London Hospital Medical College (University of London), concerning the injury done the soldier by the system of drill which include: artificial chest expansion. He say
"I found recently (some three years ago) when giving a lecture at Toynbee Hall, that il the models which had been provided for me

from the Army Medical Corps could not take an abdominal breath. They had absolntely lost the normal manner of breathing. They were emphyrematous, although young. The plastia tiesne of their longa, 80 essential for a free pal. monary circulation, was more or less destroyed, and all the conditions of cardiao hypertrophy were present. Scientifio investigations have proved that the muscles and the respiratory movements help to carry on the systemio circulation to a greater extent than was for. merly thought. In fishes, the whole systemio circulation is so carried on. By the artificial chest expansion drill, the beart has the burden of the whole circulation thrown on it. I found that the two 'modela' were typical of what was produced by snob training.' Poor devila! they are maimed, not trained."

Regarding the direct waste of the Army. we have to face the terrible fact that out of 28,600 men, in 1901, 9.000, all but sixteen, had disappeared in twelve months. Surely it is worth while to inquire into all possible causes of this wasta-a waste by invaliding and desertion. The "United Service Gezette" points to the fact that desertions are most frequent among recruits of less than three months' service. Discontent and disease lead, respectively, to desertion and invaliding. Men whose inclination would be to stick to their new oalling, if they were physically comfortable in it, desert. They are, in ninetynine cases out of a hundred, better off in the Army in many re peote than they were before joining it. But they simply cannot stand the drill. Few are Aware that what a min means wben he says he could not stand the discipline is that he could not s'and the distress, the breathlessness, the great physical strain of recruit training..

As to invaliding of yoong soldiers, this is in the main for one class of disease-viz, circola tory, or hest and lang troubles, evidenced by breathlessness and palpitatation of the heart on slight exertion, which makes men useless for work. There can, of course, be smartness, real manliness, uniformity and discipline, without injury. Unluckily, increased chest. measurement, to be arrived at in the wrong way, has got hold of the military mind. That way is to produce emphysems of the longe, and, as Professor Keith has stated, more or less destruction of the elastio power of recoil of the large and of the chest walls, by which the sot of expiration is accomplished. Boers, Japanese, Zalas koow nothing of this foolish chestswelling. They practise things they have to do in the field in the face of the enemy. They are not to be found damaging the most important organs of their bodies, the soundness of which it should be the object of all training to pre serve. But this thing, this superstition, is deeply rooted in the English military mind.

It is, perhape, needless to suggest that in the stress of battle chest-awelling is at a discount. A man taking what cover he can to fire at his enemy his no ase for chest-swelling. We want soldiers, not dolls; and it seems plain, from Colonel Pollock's interim reports, that he is making neither invalids nor deserters, but kee", enthusiastic, efficient soldiers, because he is not interfering with nature; he is giving his men sach work to do as soldiers, when passed by the medical officer, ara certified as being fit to perform.
("Pall Mall Gazstte.")
THE RIGHT HON. R. J. SEDDO
AND NEW ZEALAND.

(SPECIAL TO THE "GAZETTE") The sudden death of the New Zesland F mier in a lons not only to Maoriland, bot the whole British Empire. By the strong in vidoality and forca of his character his na had become synonymous with all that is n anmmed up in the word Imperialism. more than one ocasion, notably during t Sonth African War, the New Zealand Prem showed that he had no hesitation not on in proclaiming to all the world the fai that was in him, but also sufficient initiati to give practical proof of that forvent triotism which found 80 ready & respon in the hearts of his people.

The importance of New Zealand in Imperi questions is not to be measured by t Rtandard of her present population. Ne Zealand has not yet numbered a million, y she is capable of maintaining many million This Britain of the South has aptly be termed "The Portapata Isles." Portanates! indeed is in the possession of natural beauti of scenery unsurpassed for grandeor an variety by any other country in the who world, a temperate and equable climate, th lowest death rate (as low as 9.57 per 1,000 1904), and unlimited natural resources. speaking of the scenery of New Zealand or may be pardoned for the use of languag couched in the superlativo degree.

Writing of these Lands of the Mountain an the Flood the present High Commissioner fo New Zealand, the Hon. W. Pember Roeve says in "The Long White Clood" "The borot of these islands of mid-ooean, the grande of their Alps and fiords, the strangeness the volcanic districts, the lavishegg, ye grace, of the forests; the mixture of quain non, poetry and ferooity in the Maori, an the gallant drama of their struggle again oar overwbelming strength; the adventure of the gold-seekers and other pioneers ; tb high aims of the colony's foundere, and th venturesome democratio experiments of thos who have succeeded them."

The development of the country has bee to a great extent the work of the peopl themselves. The majority of the white popola tion is engaged in agriculture. The soil i naturally fertile. The virgin bush country has been turned into lovely pasture land Originally colonised by the best of Britie! stock who followed in the wake of the pioneer or advanced screen of missionaries, whalers and traders in the earlier years of the Victo rian era, the descendants have enjoyed the advantages of a healthy environment. To a recent arrival the first impression on landing is that most preconceived ideas of the country were wrong. The idea of its being part of Australia is no doubt due to its having beer presented to the young student of geography 49 included in the term Australasia. At no point nearer then 1,200 mile: to Australia i is as different from that continent as England is from the United States. The geological formation of the country, its fsona and fra have no reremblance to those of Australia. Ita climate is very d fferent as might have been expected from its pogition and insular situation. Its native people is of quite a diffarent, race, one much higher in the haman scale than the fast disappearing low type of aboriginal Black in Australia.

As in native races Maoriland evolved the bigbest type of eavage, 80 enthusiasts bope that it will develop the high 98t type of the Anglo-Saxon variety. If prowess in the field, both of war and sport, count for much, then the present type of young New Zealander bids tair to realize such a propbecy.

No better evidence of the colonizing powers of the British race can be cited than that of the development of New Zealand, no better exponent or epitome of the characteristic of the colonist than that of her late Premier. Maoriland has never lacked public men of spirit and ability. It has been duo in great measure to the foresight and genins of her statesmen that she commands the high position she holds to-day.

Perhaps there is no country in the world which has on its statate books 80 many measures passed more in the interest of the many than the few, showing an advanced stage of social and political development. Universal manhood saffrage, women's franchise, old-age pensions, conciliation and arbitration, state life and fire insurance, advances to settlers, prohibition, nationalization of railways, penny postage, pablio trust office, first Ministry of Pablic Health with advanced sanitary legislatare, the happy solation of the native and education questions, and many other subjects still under discussion by and worrying less fortunate co pantners in the Empire have all passed the experimental stage in New Zealand. In the advancement of much of this legislature,
Bet
V might we almost say sometimes its inception,
Mr. Seddon played a part in placing the land of big adoption in its present proud position ag the pioneer of progress in political development,

Whilst the late Premier himself was always ready to admit that New Zealand made bim, there are few who would depy Mr. Seddon the honour of baving contributed much to the well-being of New Zealand. It says much for

be mogue'io personality of that far seeing imperialistio statesman that in Boradical & country, baving a universal franchise and a government in the main democratic, he should have attained soch a position of authority.

To understand recent New Zealand politics one must reooguise the great power Mr. Seddon bad in that country. There was no department of state in which his influence was not felt. It has almost invariably been an influence for
progress and reform. vl Mr. Seddon W18 an idealist. Volike many
such he was blessed with an indomitable spirit
of initiative, perseverance, and energy. What tl other political idealists talked of he carried

into effect. He always had the good will of his people behind him. It was not so much that he interpreted poblio opinion as that he directed it. There was no hesitation or sbilly-sballying aboat "Dick," as he was familiarly known. For him to think wss to act. Like another statesman his instincts were always good, but he was not one to bury his meditations in & lonely farrow. How great a factor Mr. Seddon was in leading public opinion in New Zealand can only be reslized by those who osmo directly ander the influence of the enthusiasm of this man who, with the mind of & statesman, the courage of a soldier, tbe judgment of a philosopher, the sentiment of a poet, and the heart of a schoolboy, was able to inspire a whole people.

It is interesting to note that responsible government was granted to New Zealand in | 1856 and since that time there bave been no less than twenty-seven Ministries. As Premier Mr. Seddon has held bis 'position nearly as many years as was the average tenore in office of his twenty-six predecessors. How did this man achieve 80 mooh ? By work, bard graft as they call it in N.Z., backed op by a determination almost soperhoman in its intensity. .

Mr. Seddon commenced life in the Colonies as an employé in the Government engine sbops in Melbourne. It was wbilet there that he met Mrs. Seddon, to whose ipfigence the present writer has heard him ascribe all his success. Coming to the West Coast of New Zealand at the time of the Gold Rash he first came into prominence among bis fellows, strange to say, for his powers in the ring. Oft has the story ben told of how "Dick Seddon" with his fists won the respect of the rough diggers of Kamara by koockiog out in a few rounds a truculent bally, the terror of the tenderfoot and new chum.

But "Dick" was soon to abide in another sphere. Elected to the local board he soon became ita chairman, and later, when the digtriot attained sufficient importance to gain representation in the House of Representative, Mr. Siddod became the first member for Kumara - she has never had another. Prom the time ho entered the House he set himself the task of showing by a strenuous life of bard work, self education, and denial that the confidenca of his fellows was not misplaced. Sir George Grey, a statesman to whom New Zesland as well as Boath Africa owes much, who had the unique experience of holding the positions at different periods of both Governor and Premier of the former Colony, seems to have seen some promise in the tall, stalwart, lasty cbampion of Kamara.

At a critical time in the affairs of New Zealand the Labour Party gained the asceаdency and a Ministry was formed onder the Hon. John Ballanca. Bat death cut short the promising career of that statesman. To the sa prise of many, and the chagrin of some who imme diately foretold the rain of the colony, Mr. Seddon took over the destinies of the party and in his hands thg reing of government had remained ever since.

From that time, in spite of all prognosticstions to the contrary, in the tree of an organisod and bitter opposition fall of captious critipisms and attempted witticisms against the daring of her leader, New Zualan i entered on & new era of progress, prosperity, and industrial development.

Oocasionslly Mr. Seddon in later years, in one of his forcible and characteristic election addresses, after describing the condition of those days reminiscent of meetings of anemp!oyed and even soup kitchens, would draw a sharp contrast with the coadition of almost aniversal prosperity and contentment which bad gradually been evolved.

Mr. Seddon came into prominence in the larger sphere of Imperial politics at the first Colonial Conferenca. His personality and indi. viduality were such as appealed to the man in the strest, to say nothing of the

man in the park. When the troobles of th Uitlanders in the Transvaal onder tha Kroge regime wers worked op to an agate phase Mr. Seddon gave vojoe to the feelings of mos colonists on th) sobject of the w.o 34 of our kinemen in South Africa.

In the enthusiasm created throogboat thBmpire by an appeal to arms Mr. Seddon took a leading place. By his vigorous and robust speech and the prompt despatch of contingents ho in Do small measure fanned the Alime of loyalty to the Motherland...

As the war dragged on from months to years Mr. Beddon's call for volunteers became more insistent, and the respon#9 at each call in creased until by the end of the war N.Z. had contributed nearly seven thousand toen How well the colonial troops fought in South Atrion is now a matter of history. Io thank ing New Zealand in April, 1901, for farther troops the following appears in a wire: "Kit chener to Seddon. Wherever they have been engaged New Zealanders baye always distinguished themselves."

The writor remembers the enthusiastio receptions accorded to Mr. Seddon when he visited the chief cities of South Africa towards the end of the Boer war. In Cape Town, after hearing his characteristically forcible address brimming with the strong Imperialistio spirit, one heard on all sides the New Zealand Premier likened to their own great Empire, Builder, the at that time recently deceased C. J. Rhodes. Like Cecil J. Rhodes he was a big man with a big beart, a big mind, and blessed with an imagination which allowed him also "to think in continente."

There were not wanting those who accused him of being lacking in a doe sense of perspeotivo, of even being domineering and tyrannical Bat "King Dick," as he came to be called originally by his detractors, but later by his more numerous admirers, was in every sense of the word a man to inspire men. His name will go down to posterity as that of one of the Great Eöglanders who scorned the posil animous policies of Little Englanders as being anworthy of the best traditions of the British
race.

It is furtanate that his 8000888or, alacat Barely Sir Joseph Ward, tbe present Minister of Railways, Pablic Health, and Postmaster General, the trusty lieutenant and banchman of the late Hon. R. J. Seddon, will carry on the polioy of the party of progress in New Zealand. There has been practically little opposition to the present Government in that country and 8000e8sive elections have shown that opposition to be an ever diminishing quantity.

Sir Joseph Ward is himself a man who h28 risen soperior to cirou mstances of initial environment, and not only availed himself of opportanities, but created them. He has shown that he is pre emineat'y the one man fitted to take up the mantle of him whose prematare loss all trae lovers of the Bmpire mourn .today. The place of Mr. Seddon will be one difficult to fill, but in "J. G." the people recognise a man possessing many of the qualities of his late chit f combined with an even greater grasp of detail.
One thing is certain, that the memory of Seddon will long remain a leading factor in inspiring the progressiva people of Bagland's most listant sister state.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Manicipale s'est réanie le 19 jain. 1906 A 5 h. p.m. au palais municipal Bona la présidence de M. le Dr. Schiess proba

De l'avis conforme da Conseil do Tanzim, IA Délégation adopte une modification de mandée par l'administration des chemins de for devant la porte d'entrée de la gare do Gabbari, sous réserve de l'acceptation par oette administration de prix d'estimation d'ano paroella de terrains qui devra otre englobée dans son domaine.

Communioation est donnée des avis émis soit par los comités des Travaux Publion et des Finances réunis, soit par chacun de 088 oomités réspectivement, au sujet des diverses questions renvoyées à leur examen.
LA Délégation adopte ces différents avis at déoide de los soumettre à la Commission Municipale.
Sur la demande du Comité da Mnado, Délégation proposera à la Commission l'on verture d'un orédit de L.B. 200, à titre supplé. mentaire pour fouilles et restaurations."
Communication est donnée d'une lettre mi-1 nistérielle du 14 juin 1906 approuvant les crédits votés par la Commission dans sa séance du 6 jain 1906.

Sur l'avis favorable do Comité spécial, la Délégation proposera à la Commission la ces sion A bail, sous certaines conditions, à l'Uni. versité popolaire et au conservatoire de musi que d'un terrain situé rue de la gare da Cairo et Nébi Daniel pour l'édification d'une cons. truotion destinée aux cours et aux conférences.
La Délégation émet on avis favorable à des évaluations faites par le conseil d'estimation dans sa réance da 11 juin 1905 par divers excédents et emprison.

Communioation est donnée d'une lettre du 16 juin 1906 do 8.B. le Ministre de l'Intérionr in. formant ne le Ministère des Finances es. die posé à examiner avec bienveillance les projets relatifs à la construction de maisons à bon mar ohé et d'ane cité ouvrière,on raison de leur but philantropique tout en prenant les précautions nécessaires pour que l'entreprise ne soit pas détournés de ce bat par des motifs de spésa. lation. Le Ministère sjonte que pour que le dit projet pnisse avoir l'approbation et l'appui da Gouvernement il est essentiel que le succès de l'entreprise paraisse être assuré aussi bien au point de vue commercial qu'au point de voe humanitaire. Il demande dono À la Manicipalité de lai fournir tous les éléments d'information doet égard nécessaires pour per mettre un examen complet de la question.
Cette lettre estronvopées à l'étude da Comité des maisons ouvrières et à bon marché, lequel se réunira jeudi 21 courant.

Communioation est également donnée d'une lettre da 17 juin du Ministère de l'Intérieur informant que le Ministère des Finanoos lui a éorit qu'il regrette de ne pas partager la manière de voir de la Municipalité tondant à la vente de la paroelle des quais No 27.
La Délégation déoide de mettre en adjudica. tions les travaux de canalisation de la partie de rue d'Allemagne comprise entre la rue du Masée et la rue Mariette Pacha.
Bllo renvoie au Comité des Travaux Pablica le devis pour la construction d'au mur de sou. tènement dans la rae El Chatby.
La séance est levée à 8 h. p.m.
LES TRAMWAYS DE BEYROUTH.

A la suite de l'approbation par le Ministère des travaux publics des statuts de la Société anonyme ottomane des tramways et de l'électricité de Beyrouth," le Sultan a délivré le firman autorisant la constitution de cette société.
La nouvelle société devient concessionnaire pour 99 ans, de l'exploitation d'un réseau de tramways Beyrouth et de l'éclairage électri. que de la ville.

Cette Société a été constituée an capital de 9 millions de francs, divisé en 60,000 actions de 100 francs chacane. Treute six mille actions seront émises immédiatement ; le reste sera émis à une date à fixer par le conseil d'administration de la Société. Chaque membre du conseil d'administration devra être porteur de 50 action. Un commi saire impérial assistera aux séances du conseil.
La nouvelle société concédera dix pour cent des recettes aux chemins de fer da Hedjaz.

Ainsi que celle do tramway da Caire, cette Société est une filiale de la Société belge des chemins de fer économiq 188 dont le siège et à Bruxelles, a pour administrateur général M. Empain. M.Caldarera est le directeur de la non vella société.

Le Sapplément Commercial et Financier de l'"Egyptian Gazette" parst chaque Samedi à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichiep. Il contient des revues oomplètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der nières statistiqaes jasqu'à la veille de sa publication : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielle envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc eto.
L'abonnement, pour une année en Egypte coll te 1 L.E. y condpris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

loi, la séance de ce matin a été asscz animée. Qui plus est, il y a eu un bon courant de transactions sur certains titres, notamment sur la Barye d'Orient, le Comptoir Financier, les Biebler, les Nungoviob, l'Anglo-American Nile, les Upper Egypt, les Ciments et les Dalta Land. Il faut faire des veix pour que cette activité se maintienne..

La National Bank et l'Agricole ont olótaré plas formes qu'hier à 25 9/16 et 9 11/16. La Banqne d'Orient a gagné 3 franos et demi à 133 1 2. Le Comptoir Pinancier a avancé 6 3/16 1/4 l'action ancienne et 6 3/32 la nouvelle; la part de fondateur est remontée à 42.
Les Ciments ont passé de 65 à 69 francs et l'action privilégiée Tramways d'Alexandrie de 188. 192.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nangovich ont fait 15 23/32 l'action ancienne et 15 11/16 la nouvelle. Bo forte demande et en exoellente tenue, les Baebler ont avancé do 5 1/4 & 3 9/16-5/8; les Upper Egypt, de 41/41 4 3/8 7/16. L'Anglo-American Nile, très recherchée, a atteint 5 5/16 pour finir á 5 1/4

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont presque rattrapé le cours do 4. Les Estat98 ont progressé à 1 11/16 3/4 ; la part de fonda tonr: a hagssé à 10 1/4 5/16. Ley Egyptian Constructions ont clolaré à 11/4, les Abdy & 1 5 16, Les Glymeaopoulo à 9/16, et les Sucreries à 22-23.

La Société des Tramways d'Alexandrie vient de publier en brochure un projet d'anification des deux catégories d'actions qui constituent le capital social : les Privilégiées, au nombre de 80,000,, dont la valeur nominale est de 100 franos, et les Dividendor, an nombre de 33,000, sans désignation de valeur.
La combinaison a pour ohjat la suppression de ces dernières, on attribuant deux actions privilégiées à chaque action de dividende.
Pour arriver à ce bat en conformité de la loi belge, notamment des articles 41, 42 et 43 des Statata, la Société voters sa liquidation dans une assemblée générale convoquéa à cat effet.
Une nouvelle Société sera ensuite constituée au capital de 192,350 actions. Cette Société créera, en outre, des obliga'ions dont le conseil déterminera le typa, la-valear, etc.
En votant la liquidation de la Société, l'ae. semblée générale nommera an liquidatgur qui cèdera l'avoir et les charge de la Spoiété.

De ce titre), 80,000 seront attribués à l'ancien capital privilégié ; le solde, soit 113,350, qui constituara un bénéfice, sera distribué au prorata de 2/9 ou 22.22 % aux actions privi légiéss et 7/9 on 77.78 % aux actions de id vidende.
Bref, l'attribution d'actions pouvelle: faite à chaque acttion de dividende sera le double de l'attribution qai sera faite à chaque action privilégiée actuelle.

Le conseil d'administration de la nouvelle Société émettra 20,000 obligations de 500 francs, dont le montant sera affecté : 1° à l'é. change ou au remboursement des 15,554 obligations anciennes; % au paiement des frais d'émission, échange des obligations, etc.; 3° à l'établissement de nouvelles lignes, extension da l'asine, achat de matériel roulant, fonds de roulement, etc.

On répète que la Société Walker and Meimarachi Ltd. aurait définitivement décidé de faire construire se nouveaux magasins du quartier Ismailieh sur la moitié seulement du terrain acheté à côté de l'Agence de France. Les travaux ne seraient commencés que lorsI que les nouveaux plans seraient terminés et approuvés.
Le terrain disponible, environ 2,000 mètres, serait mis en vente. Oa prétend que la Société aurait refusé ane offre de £50,000 ; elle de manderait £60,000 soit 30 £ le métre.

Un journal de Bruxelles vient de publier les tableau des recettes des principales entreprisea de tramways pendant les mois d'Avril 1905 et 1906, ainsi que pendant les quatres premiers mois des mêmes années.

Il ressort de cette statistique que la plasvalue la plus remarquable a été celle des Tram ways da Caire, dont les recettes se sont élevées pour le mois d'Avril, de Pre. 363,636 en 1995 à 446,869 en 1906, et, pour la période da 1er Janvier au 30 Avril de Prs. 1,342,027 à 1,683,212, ce qui accuse des plas-values de Prs. 83.233 et 341,183.

div.head: ÆGYPTIACA.
div.p: BY JOSEPH OFFORD.

In a former portion of Ægyptiaca mentio was made of an Egyptian soal in the form an Assyrian oylinder bearing the oartonoh Rumores II. of the 19th dynasty, as being s Inte in date for that type of signet in Bgypt that it may have been of Syrian workmanship The whole subjeot of the use of this Mesopo tamian cylindrical form of seal by the Bzyptinn bs been somewhat fully treated in Chapter of M. Peroy E Newberry's recint'y pablisbe book entitled Scarabs," "An Introdaction to the Study of Bzyptian Seal and Signet Rings.'

He therein figares a cylinder of Seti I, pre decessor of Rameses II, with the comment that it is one of the latest specimens of oylinder known. From the reprezentation of it given it appears to be in perfeot preservation and is interesting for tbe trellis work ornament running right round the cylinder ooonpying half its depth. This relo is in the Petrie collection at University College, London.

There are cylinders bearing the names of private personego as late as the 26th dynasty but they are extremely rare. There is, however, no great antiquarian difficulty in socepting the Ramoses specimen as Egyptian work.

Mr. Nuwberry gives copies of quite 100 Egyptian aylinders commencing with that of Pharaoh Narmer perhaps a pre-Menes monArch, and terminating as late as the 26th dypasty, bat these very late ones are not those of royalty.

The reliefs npon the Narmer ard Zer cylinders (the latter successor of Menes) are far noperior in artistio merit to many archaio Egyptian specimens, which should therefore be considered to represent products of a much esrlier period.

It will immediately appear that if this is the oase, and if this form of seal was introduced into tbe Nile valley by Babylonian, or Blamite, invaders, then their incoming to Bgypt, from Asin, must bave taken place under chieftains earlier than those whose names we have at the Menes era, or of the whom somo Egyptoloxista consider a9 prelocessors of Nanes. The short thiok torm of cylinder, praotically identical in type with the early Chaldean and Elamite cylinders, and also, in many instance, bearing figoros closely allied to those of Babylonian representations, are evidently the work of a period far anterior to thore we know to date from the first dynasty.

The abort, and what may be termed pre historio, oylinders have been fogod asac ciated with larger ones in tombs of the first dyoanty, but the first form was apparently at this early time a survival, for it vapisbes about the data of King Zer in the first dynasty, whilst tbe long ones continued in general 088 to the end of the sixth dynasty. A fine member of one of the last of its kind, bearing the title of Merira, is in the Piers oollection in the United States.

The cylinders of the Shepherd, or Hyksos, Kings do not show any great difference of design from Egyptian ones of about the samo era. One of King Khyan in the Cairo Morenm is however partidalar'y small in diameter,
whilst being rather long. riz, about it • inohes, having a resemblance in size to an ivory needle care.

Scme of the very arcbsio cylinders have for a familiar device the head and fore legs of an animal reversed, that is to say a fan tastic animal with beads and fore quarters looking in opposite direetions united together. It M. Newberry says this is not an Egyptian motive, but it coours upon the prehistorio cowbs figured by M. Capart. Mr. Newberry fartber sugrats it is a design emanating from the Delta. If so it is extremely inte resting that it was a favourite form of orna ment upon some prehistorio antiqnities from Sardinia and Sicily

The royal oylinder of Zer is very simple, bot significant, in its tableats. These ara two totem guidons with the jackal nome symbol. Then the king's Horos name, with the Horus faloon surmounting it, and then sented figures of Zer, one bearing the crown of upper and other of lower Egypt. So at the time it was graven the idea of uniting the two in one symbolio headdre-8, as was usual, later or, had not been conceived.

Cylinders have been found of copper and bronze but the majority are of black steatite or the white variety, glazed artificially green or blue, Mapy are of ivory, bæmatite, and green j' per ; but from the many impressions lo upon clay that have been preserved it is ri evident that the commodest material utili ed was wool, and a few woeden ones have been found.

The use of this form of seal provides perhaps the most weighty argoment for the connection, at some period, in Egypt of African with Asiatic civilisation, if such a term may be used in in speaking of such early races of mankiad, m Perbaps on the western littoral of the Red Sea Iph around Kosseir, or near Scakir, or at Port Sudar, specimens of cylinders left by voyagers from Asis to Egypt may be found supplying
connecting link between thoee of the Chaldeans and the Egyptians.

GERMS LIVE IN MUMMIES.
PAD FOR EGYPTIAN RELICS HAS SPREAD GREAT WHITE SCOURGE.

Chicago, May 12. – "Bgyptology verans Hesith" was the title of a monograph, received at the bes dq narters cf the Tuberculosis Institate of Chicago yesterday, in which it was alleged bat the great spread of tabercolosia in Europe and America in the last 100 years foord its cause in the di interment and shipment broadcast over the land of the mommies I which had reposed so long in the tombs of the Pharaohs. The monograph was written by Dr. Rafaelle Sorgoar, one of the lecturers at the Sorbonne in Paris, who was an interested visitor at the recent taberculosis exhibition in this city.

"That the disinterred mommies started the spread of the t.berculosis germs in Bzypt cannot be doubted," says Dr. Sorgpac in bis 10 monograph. "There are more tubercolosis:03 germs in the almost impalpable dust around a ou mummy C9se than in many cuspidors of, ou efflavia These germa live for thousands of years, as has easily been proven, and the

me exhumation pf the bodies, ev 3n the well preserved ones, caused an epidemic of consumpti n among the workmen and scholsra who first exhumed the cases. It is also well known that the keepers of the mommy Cases have been suhjeet to the diseas

"The start of tuberculosis in France in a Feriods sepse may be traced to the great im portation of mummies and mummy care at the time of the Napoleonic invasion of Bzypt, and this start gave the disease its first great foothold in Europe, whence it has spread all over the western world. Dead bodies may not secrete the germs, but desd dodies are undoubtedly a favourite lodging place for the tubercular ba
arr
cilli.

"The bacilli from tbemommies are undoubtedly of great age, and it bas been ebcwp by! experiment in Paris that these aged becilli are infinitely more deadly tban those obtained from the live persons who are infected."

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--

to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic

than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
